title: Myer spring/summer fashion launch showcases aspirational brands
text:
Myer launched its new spring/summer collection at the Carriageworks in Sydney on Thursday. Dallas Kilponen Share on twitter by Sue Mitchell It's a pity Myer shareholders were few and far between on the guest list at the retailer's spring fashion launch on Thursday night.
The parade provided a sneak peek of the significant changes set to occur in Myer's 67 stores as new chief executive Richard Umbers and chief merchandise and marketing officer Daniel Bracken attempt to reverse a 20-year slide in sales by making Myer's offer more relevant to customers.
Rather than being a one-stop shop for fashion, accessories and homewares, Myer believes the future for department stores is in offering a curated range that better reflects the needs and aspirations of shoppers.
Hence, the spring parade featured fewer brands than in past years – 27 rather than 35 or 40 – but showcased a deeper range, mirroring Myer's new strategy in stores.
Late last month Myer culled about 100 national and international brands and kicked off a multimillion dollar "spring clean" sale to clear floor space for new labels, including Aje, Jack and Jones, Daniel Avakian and Calvin Klein White Label.
"We've edited down the number of brands and designers so they can show in much greater depth," Mr Bracken said. "Many brands are showing eight, 10 or 20 looks [rather than four or five] at a time."
"I'd rather us pack in the best brands presented well rather than a lot of brands presented in a very minimal way," the former Burberry executive said.
"If we can get the right offering and the right brands in our stores for our customers why would they want to traipse around a shopping mall."

The show was also bigger than in past years, with 450 guests jostling for 200 coveted front-row seats set against a dramatic backdrop of more than 5000 bird-of-paradise flowers.
Consistent with Myer's new focus on digital technology to better understand and communicate with customers, the parade was beamed to social media followers on Periscope, Snapchat, Instagram, Twitter and Facebook.
Like Donna Player, group merchandise director at arch rival David Jones, which launched its spring/summer collection last week, Mr Bracken believes this season's looks are more accessible than aspirational.
"I think it's very, very wearable," said Mr Bracken, who eschewed Burberry for a Dom Bagnato suit and MJ Bale shirt.
"The largest trend we're showcasing, because it's the largest trend globally, is the continuation of the monochrome trend, which is incredibly accessible," he said.
Other trends include lace and florals, nautical stripes and crisp whites for women, and "washed out" blue and mint and chambray for men.
"It's a beautifully curated collection that provides great selling opportunities for our stores," Mr Bracken said.
Shareholders, who have seen the value of their shares halve since Myer proposed a merger with David Jones last year, can only hope he's right.
